text:
Stay up to date with our most recent news and updates Feb 21 Posted on February 21, 2017 by Josh Hall in Divi Resources | 11 comments 
Welcome to part 2 of 5 of our Divi mini series Creating Client Documentation to Empower your Clients and Save You Time . In this series, we‚Äôre branching out from a typical module or Divi design tutorial by showing you 5 ways you can create Client Documentation with the primary purposes of educating and empowering your clients and in the process, saving you time. 
Investing in a website design can be a very intimidating and overwhelming process for a client. It‚Äôs our job as the web developer to prepare them on how the process works, what tools we use, etc. What better way to do that than with a getting started page? 
I found myself repeating my process and tools to new clients over and over until finally creating a getting started page. Now when a project begins, I send my page to the client to review before we dive into design and development. I‚Äôve found that this has alleviated most if not all initial questions my clients have before a project begins. 
Alright, let‚Äôs dive in and give you some ideas on how you might create a getting started page for your clients! Creating a Getting Started Page for Your New Clients 
Here‚Äôs what my page looks like: How This Can Benefit You 
Having a link that you can send to a client that outlines your development process, tools and need-to-know items will save you time . You‚Äôll avoid countless incoming emails and calls from clients who may be confused about the collaboration tools you use, your process and what to expect when a project gets underway. It‚Äôll also help you better articulate and refine your process when you‚Äôre able to explain it visually in one web page. It reflects very well on you as a designer if you have a proven step by step process that‚Äôs easy to follow. How This Can Benefit Your Client 
With a getting started page, you can help make your client feel comfortable, informed and excited about the web design experience . Remember, you as a web designer are selling much more than a product or service; you‚Äôre selling a web design experience! You should want your client to feel excited and informed from the get go. Creating a Getting Started page is a great way for the client to see the process, know what to expect and know what‚Äôs expected of them as the project begins. Implementing a ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù Page on Your Website 
I‚Äôll go over in detail what‚Äôs in my page and will hopefully encourage you think about what you may put in yours. 
I created an intro video that briefly goes over my getting started process. Since I don‚Äôt often meet all my clients in person, I‚Äôve found this a great way to make them feel more comfortable and get to know me a little better before the project starts. 1. A Basic Overview of What I Need to Get Started on a Project 
This is all information that most all web designers should get before diving into a project. By listing this out (in bullets) it helps the client know what to get together and what‚Äôs expected of them before getting started on the new site. 
There‚Äôs nothing worse than waiting on content from a client and though that‚Äôs a never ending struggle for designers, I‚Äôve found this is a good place to start. This will also help you avoid any unpleasant situations where the clients gives you nothing then two weeks later is asking how the new site is coming. By sending this information to the client up front, they know you need this before you start designing. 
Here‚Äôs what I ask for: ‚Ä¢ Your Logo (PDF, EPS or high res JPEG if possible) ‚Ä¢ Hosting Login (hosting account and/or Cpanel login) ‚Ä¢ Current Website Login (if currently a WordPress site) ‚Ä¢ Images or any new pictures you‚Äôd like to use for the new site ‚Ä¢ Brand style guide, colors or any special graphics being used 2. Basecamp (or any particular project management software you might use) 
I use Basecamp to help me manage all my projects. It‚Äôs a great tool for collaboration with clients and fellow team members. When I started using this however, I found that my clients were confused when they got emails from Basecamp. I realized very quickly that I needed to inform my clients up front that we‚Äôd be using this platform to track progress and share content. I also make sure to explain the benefits. In this case; to avoid loosing messages in email threads, to create organized discussions, to do lists, etc. 
Here‚Äôs what I tell my client: 
Basecamp is an awesome online platform for communication and project management. We‚Äôll be using this to send messages, share files and track progress during the process. This will help alleviate content and images being lost in long email threads. Everyone loves email threads‚Ä¶right?! (Don‚Äôt worry you can still use your email. The messages will post directly to basecamp!) Once your project is underway, you‚Äôll receive an email to set up your basecamp profile and we‚Äôll be off and running! 3. Dropbox (or whatever image transfer program you may use) 
I also use Dropbox for projects with several galleries and images. Though I tell my clients often use basecamp for image and content transfers, if there is a project with 50 to 100 images or more, I let them know about dropbox. This often helps me avoid getting multiple emails with 2-3 images per email when the client knows that we‚Äôll be using this or basecamp to organize and collect images. 
Here‚Äôs what I tell my client: 
Dropbox is a great online image/file sharing platform. This isn‚Äôt necessary for every project, but if you have more than 15-20 images for your website or if they‚Äôre too big to send through email or post on basecamp, we can use dropbox. We can also use this to share important logins and credentials instead of sending through email. I will set up a folder for the project and will share the folder with you via email. You can upload all images and files there. 4. The Development Process 
It‚Äôs very important for the client to know and understand your design/development process. This will not only help your client understand what‚Äôs going on day to day but is also a good way to set expectations. I simplified and explain my process in 3 steps: 
Here‚Äôs what I tell my client: 
THE DESIGN PROCESS Designing a website, no matter how big or small, is an extensive process that can be overwhelming. I‚Äôve outlined my process into 3 steps: 
STEP 1 ‚Äì LAYOUT AND DESIGN A large and time consuming part of website design is in the layout, structure and design of the site. I‚Äôll create the framework of the website and will send the homepage and a sub-page (or more upon request) for approval. 
STEP 2 ‚Äì DEVELOPMENT Once the site layout and design is approved, I‚Äôll move forward with the designing of all pages, functionality and responsive code, making sure your site looks great and functions nicely across all devices and web browsers. 
STEP 3 ‚Äì REVISIONS AND EDITS Once the site is ready for final review, you‚Äôll be able to review each page and we can make detailed edits until the site is revised completely. 
I‚Äôve found that when a client turns their project over to a developer, they want to know how the process works and what to expect. By laying out your process in simple terms, you can help your client feel at ease when the project begins. I accent this on my page by using the blurb module icons and putting a nice background image to help make this very important section ‚Äúpop.‚Äù 5. Preparing for Launch 
I‚Äôve found that many clients are also initially interested in the ‚Äúgoing live‚Äù process so I try to give them some basic information so they know what to expect before we go live with the new site. I give information to our website security and maintenance plan as well as letting them know that they‚Äôll receive information and our recommendations on ‚Äúmoving forward‚Äù with their new site once it‚Äôs live. 
Here‚Äôs what I tell my client: Once the site is ready to go live, all unnecessary plugins, pages, images and backend files will be removed. The new site will be backed up and saved locally, should it ever need restored. Once live, please allow 24-48 hours for propagation to occur. Some computers will need to be refreshed in order to see the new site, though most computers will see the new site immediately depending on the wifi connection. 
Your website logins and all credentials will be sent to you via basecamp or email insuring the security of your passwords. Though your logins and passwords will be saved locally, PLEASE SAVE ALL LOGINS FOR YOUR RECORDS AS WELL. 
Upon completion, you‚Äôll receive a link to my ‚Äúmoving forward‚Äù process where you‚Äôll receive tips and tricks on marketing your new website and also information on our Maintenance/Security Plan which I highly recommend for all my clients. 6. Final Link or Call-to-Action 
Finally, I have a link to my website questionnaire if a client didn‚Äôt happen to fill that out. More often than not, a client gets this after filling out the form but I‚Äôve found it good to have a link there just incase. 
Well I hope the idea of a ‚Äúgetting started‚Äù page inspires you to better prepare your clients before getting started on a project! I have found this very useful in helping me avoid repeating the same thing over and over to new clients and I‚Äôve also found that clients are very appreciative and excited when they know what to expect before the web design experience begins! Tomorrow: Creating a ‚ÄúMoving Forward‚Äù Page for Your Clients 
Tomorrow we‚Äôll talk about creating a ‚ÄúMoving Forward‚Äù page for your clients and I‚Äôll give you the recommendations that I offer my clients to help them utilize and grow their new website; all of which you‚Äôre welcome to share with your clients as well üôÇ

By Josh Hall Josh is a web developer/graphic designer based in Columbus, Ohio. As the owner of In Transit Studios, he partners with small to medium size businesses to help them grow by creating their branding, marketing materials and websites using Wordpress and Divi.
